1125511160084795392.text: Answer to myself: only a limited range of legacy 8051 registers is bit addressable (0x20..0x2f). 5/5

... 3 or 4 retransmits. Thus results are slightly biased, as the PTX never receives an ack.
- will push the test code to github, once working
- haven't implemented channel change for "promiscuous", though

1098228921106137089.text:
4/n
- 16 bit shifts could be done reliably, doing more would take too much time in an ISR (next IRQ from RF arrives rapidly)
- bitwise crc checking with 16 bit shifting succeeds for about 50% of raw frames which contain the target address
- the ptx sends only once, but with ...

1098227741630050304.text:
3/n
- as most hits are on 0xaaaa, the rx ISR skips full 0xaa bytes on received buffer
- next step is to check crc (accounting for length in assumed PCF)
- if CRC check fails, whole rx buffer is left shifted 1 bit and crc check repeated

1098226881260859393.text:
2/n
- utilizing all pipes for capture (adresses 0xa8aa, aa1f, aa9f, aaa8, aaa9, aa8f, aaaa)
- most hits on aaaa, but real rf frame occurs very late in rx buffer
- rx buffer stores 60 bytes after address match (more than 200 possible on nRF52)

1098225839903264768.text:
1/n
Working in progress  ESB promiscous mode for nRF52840

@travisgoodspeed 
- output of captured RF frames grepped for target address bb0adc
- rf payload starts at 2nd byte
- first byte shows pipe no in lower nibble, higher nibble is 4 if crc matchpic.twitter.com/IMewtBAJND

1097469630619312128.text:
1/2

Quick heads up:
For nrf52840 addrLen=1 with prefixLen=1 works, if first 2 address octets of PTX are known.
Setting addr+prefix to 00aa or 0055 doesn't result in meaningful frames.

AddrLen=0 works, too ... again no meaningful results

Due to Floating Point emulation, Linux MIPS (Kernels 2.4.3.4 through 4.7 2001-2016) have executable stacks.

The patch, released in 2016 and still present - Kernel 4.8, introduces a universal DEP and ASLR bypass.

1124401003208544259.text: And with the TI 84+ C Silver Edition, TI reused the community's trick to defeat their own write protection!pic.twitter.com/MS7FdujkqU

1124400720185298945.text: And lo, they modified the boot page to disable the signature check, and it was good!pic.twitter.com/aEtSGc5Jhv

1124400559828688896.text: 84+ and 84+ silver edition are the same software, with checks for IO port to know where the topmost page is mapped.  But also writing to port 21 control the write locking, so they can modify the boot code!pic.twitter.com/96FcNkH3wE

1124399494232248320.text: The length field isn't checked, so they can overflow all of RAM into corrupting the call stack!pic.twitter.com/NSSawc6Pqb

1124399145941336065.text: So then TI switches to RSA2048, which takes SIX MINUTES on an eight bit micro!  A new exploit is needed.pic.twitter.com/TT5t7Wd1Tc

1124398760002510850.text:
But software bugs come and go, and even with a large collection, it might run out.  So one guy on one PC factored the RSA512 key in one month!

TI scared him silent with a house call, so the community factored the remaining keys!

Kind thanks to the @EFF for saving the day!pic.twitter.com/b74pvgn8EF

1124397675103891457.text:
But what they really wanted was a universal exploit, that wasn't model specific.

So they considered that the smallest app was larger than RAM and must be written in pieces, and they might repurpose this as a ram to ram memcpy.pic.twitter.com/CcUmZHkmX3

1124396904274591744.text: 83+ Silver Edition has an extra memory bank, whose mapping they forgot to check!  This lets them mirror banks to corrupt the return pointer, allowing a return to the exploit while flash is still unlocked!pic.twitter.com/ofPe2l4N0y

1124396263837974531.text: Another brilliant trick that can't quite work involves executing off-by-one, so that the right bytes are read but they execute very differently.pic.twitter.com/wrM89DCnyX

1124395965031567362.text: The stack pointer trick they check for would be to have the stack in ROM, returning to the wrong address.  Sadly, they check for it.pic.twitter.com/jvDCaLIYgW

1124395594276069377.text: They check for tricky stack addresses and page mappings.pic.twitter.com/b0uM7tp7so

1124395082436829185.text: He's now explaining how the Z80 devices lock their flash memory.  There us a simple sequence of instructions, but they *must* run from a privileged page and interrupts are disabled.  You can't modify the OS unless you are the OS, or you are clever.pic.twitter.com/Fig1Q5BKbN

1124394173958897665.text: Press-to-Test is a key combo that locks the calculator out of advanced features until it's connected to a computer, so if you don't like somebody, you can quickly hit three buttons and they can't do their classwork!pic.twitter.com/5Z957pgoLs

1124393729215877122.text: "So you had to pay good money to sign free applications!"pic.twitter.com/GGpAssFyhA

1124392801893060608.text: Hardware is identical, but they really want to keep the European firmware on the right from running on the American model on the left.pic.twitter.com/zi1uClzqXc

1124392255429709827.text: "I don't want to offend anybody, but I really hate these models."pic.twitter.com/BkwdGcV9mx

1124391573872160769.text: TI 83 had a backdoor in Send(), and for the TI 86, they made it an official feature with public documentation and OS hooks!pic.twitter.com/6302pzNx6t

1124391272645636096.text: TI 82 had no Custom Menu, but it still had RAM backups, so they changed the address of a variable to be CxMain and then copied an address into it from a real variable!pic.twitter.com/lkNuPc7o4v

1124390570074497027.text: ZSHELL on the TI-85 executes native code by patching a function pointer in the Custom Menu through a patched backup of SRAM.  You can then run other native code from string variables.pic.twitter.com/yK3eRupqc7

1124389625408176129.text: He has one of every model, including engineering prototypes and development samples.pic.twitter.com/DCY2R9YiKg

1124340706749943808.text: And knowing the stages, she can measure which resources each stage accesses, in order to know the implicit rules for what good page permissions might be.pic.twitter.com/8bgV8WccCz

1124340266092171270.text: Combining this with uboot's call graph, she can divide uboot's behavior into stages behaviorally, more accurately than by reading the code.pic.twitter.com/CIkasXamdy

1124339682962178049.text: She logs all memcpy()-type calls, then works backward from that to divide them by purpose.  (Reading SD card, zeroing the .bss region, etc.)pic.twitter.com/wGy6yq5zBm

1124338761582694400.text:
Her toolsuite instruments a real bootloader process through GCC, as a way to measure and test write restrictions.
https://typedregions.com pic.twitter.com/DLZ0SeopGF

1124337645444841473.text:
You can even have your image be loaded *into I/O*!

"What you are loading tells you what it needs, and it is the loader's responsibility to know whether this is safe."pic.twitter.com/HsAl0Ziv19

1124337214702465025.text: Generally all of these IO registers are available to the bootloader, even at times when they aren't needed.  Bx proposes that an MMU might enforce access to these pages, just as it does to RAM pages.pic.twitter.com/hAzzbESjMx

1124334778898161665.text:
A few years back, Bx found a way to make an ELF loader parse its own output as metadata.  This and a fancy trick for calling I/O functions gave a complete brainfuck implementation that runs before loading completes!
https://github.com/bx/elf-bf-tools pic.twitter.com/DgdYJAXEQn

1124333367724531712.text: In Bx' view, a bootloader is just another type of executable loader.  ELF, PE or Uboot, they are still loading a program into memory before jumping into it.pic.twitter.com/becO4nGaPv
